cmCourseInfo.description: This the first part of a sequence of two courses designed to introduce theory, contemporary topics, and analytical techniques related to the study of health issues. Examples of topics include: social determinants of health, basic anatomy, introduction to child development, introduction to the life course and aging, disease, health economics and policy, and applicable research methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations in Health Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: This the second part of a sequence of two courses designed to introduce theory, contemporary topics, and analytical techniques related to the study of health issues. Examples of topics include: social determinants of health, basic anatomy, introduction to child development, introduction to the life course and aging, disease, health economics and policy, and applicable research methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations in Health Studies II

cmCourseInfo.description: The objective of this course is to introduce students to the main principles that are needed to undertake health-related research. Students will be introduced to the concepts and approaches to health research, the nature of scientific inquiry, the role of empirical research, and epidemiological research designs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health Research Methodology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [HLTA02H3 and HLTA03H3 and any Statistics course] or [any 4.0 credits, including SOCB60H3]

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will present a brief history about the origins and development of the public health system and its role in health prevention. Using a case study approach, the course will focus on core functions, public health practices, and the relationship of public health with the overall health system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Public Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Period 1: Initially restricted to students in the Major programs in Health Studies (Health Policy or Population Science; co-op and non co-op).
Period 2: Shortly after 11:00am on Monday, April 4th any remaining spaces in this course may open to other UTSC students.

You may enroll in this course if you have the pre-requisites completed. Please check the Health Studies section of the course calendar for listed pre-requisites. Students that do not have the pre-requisites in place may be removed without notification.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on public and private financing mechanisms for health care in Canada, emphasizing provincial differences and discussing the systems in place in other developed nations. Topics will include the forces of market competition and government regulation as well as the impact of health policy on key stakeholders. Students will also learn how to apply simple economic reasoning to examine health policy issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Policy and Health Systems

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Period 1: Initially restricted to students in the Major programs in Health Studies (Health Policy or Population Science; co-op and non co-op).
Period 2: Shortly after 11:00am on Monday, April 4th any remaining spaces in this course may open to other UTSC students.

You may enroll in this course if you have the pre-requisites completed. Please check the Health Studies section of the course calendar for listed pre-requisites. Students that do not have the pre-requisites in place may be removed without notification.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to human health through literature, narrative, and the visual arts. Students will develop strong critical skills in text-centered methods of analysis (i.e., the written word, visual images) through topics including representations of health, illness narratives, death and dying, patient-professional relationships, technoscience and the human body.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health Humanities
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Prior experience in humanities courses at the secondary or post-secondary level.
cmCourseInfo.note: Preference will be given to students enrolled in a Health Studies program.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the fundamental concepts in health informatics (HI) and the relevance of HI to current and future Canadian and international health systems. Students will be introduced to traditional hospital-based/clinician-based HI systems, as well as present and emerging applications in consumer and public HI, including global applications.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health Information Systems
cmCourseInfo.note: Priority will be given to students enrolled in the Major/Major Co-op programs in Health Studies.

courses.name: Health, Aging and the Life Cycle

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on the transition from birth to old age and changes in health status. Topics to be covered include: socio-cultural perspectives on aging, the aging process, chronic and degenerative diseases, caring for the elderly.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health, Aging and the Life Cycle

courses.name: Issues in Child Health and Development

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will explore bio-social aspects of health and development in children. Topics for discussion include genetics and development, growth and development, childhood diseases, the immune system, and nutrition during the early years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Child Health and Development

cmCourseInfo.description: Epidemiology is the study or the pattern and causes of health-related outcomes and the application of findings to improvement of public health. This course will examine the history of epidemiology and its principles and terminology, measures of disease occurrence, study design, and application of concepts to specific research areas.
cmCourseInfo.title: Community Health and Epidemiology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [HLTB15H3 and HLTB16H3 and any statistics course] or [enrolment in the Certificate in Computational Social Science]
cmCourseInfo.note: Priority will be given to students enrolled in the Major/Major Co-op programs in Health Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of a current topic in Health Humanities. The specific topic will vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Humanities

cmCourseInfo.description: This is an advanced reading course in special topics for upper level students who have completed the available basic courses in Health Studies and who wish to pursue further intensive study on a relevant topic. Topic selection and approval will depend on the supervising instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Readings in Health Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of at least 6.0 credits, including at least 1.5 credits at the C-level from the program requirements from one of the Major/Major Co-op programs in Health Studies; students must also have achieved a minimum CGPA of 2.5 and have permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: A
SUPERVISED STUDY/RESEARCH & INDEPENDENT STUDY COURSES
Step 1: Request the course on ACORN. Your status will be INT. You will not be officially enrolled until you complete the remaining steps (below).
Step 2: Meet with the Supervisor and obtain their signature on a 'Supervised Study form'. Make sure the course code, supervisor name and title of the project is clearly printed on the form as this information will appear on your transcript. The Supervised Study form is available at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/registrar/supervised-study-form. Your Department may require additional paperwork. Students should contact the Office for more information.
Step 3: Submit the signed Supervised Study form by email to Sean Ramrattan sean.ramrattan@utoronto.ca.
The Department will arrange to have your course status on ACORN changed from interim (INT) to approved (APP).

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of contemporary issues in health research. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of at least 1.5 credits from the program requirements from one of the Major/Major Co-op programs in Health Studies
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Completion of 1.5 credits at the C-level in HLT courses

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of a current health sciences topic. The specific topic will vary from year to year, and may include: clinical epidemiology, an advanced nutrition topic, or the biology and population health impacts of a specific disease or illness condition.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Sciences
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HLTC27H3 with a minimum grade of 70%; and an additional 1.5 credits at the C-level in HLT courses from the program requirements from the Major/Major Co-op program in Health Studies - Population Health

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of contemporary issues in health research. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 1.5 credits at the C-Level in HLT courses from the program requirements from one of the Major/Major Co-op programs in Health Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of contemporary issues in health research. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 1.5 credits at the C-level in HLT courses from the program requirements from one of the Major/Major Co-operative programs in Health Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: The topics presented in this course will represent a range of contemporary issues in health research. Topics will vary by instructor and term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 1.5  credits at the C-Level in HLT courses from the program requirements from one of the Major/Major Co-operative programs in Health Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: This advanced seminar will provide intensive study of a selected topic in and/or theoretical questions about the health humanities. Topics will vary by instructor and term but may include narrative medicine, stories of illness and healing, representations of older age and aging in literature and film, AIDS and/or cancer writing, representations of death and dying in literature and film, the role of creative arts in health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Humanities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of HLTB50H3 with a minimum grade of 70% and 1.5 credits at the C-level in HLT courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: AR
Restricted to students in the Minor Program in Health Humanities and Major/Major Cooperative Programs in Health Studies.

New D-level enrollment policy:

Due to heavy demand for the D-level courses in Health Studies, effective Summer 2022, students will initially be approved into one D-level course. This is to ensure that all students that need a D-level for the purpose of completing their program requirements have the ability to add one to their timetable. If a student adds themselves to more than one D-level course, the department will only approve them into one.

Once all students that require a D-level course have had the opportunity to be approved into one, enrollment for remaining spaces will re-open and you may add yourselves to more if you wish.

You may enroll in this course if you have the pre-requisites completed. Please check the Health Studies section of the course calendar for listed pre-requisites. Students that do not have the pre-requisites in place may be removed without notification.

Check your status through ACORN to see whether you have been approved. (APP = approval; REF = refused; INT = no decision yet)
